text: I understand that it can be incredibly disappointing and painful to feel alone even when surrounded by people. It's essential to understand that feelings of loneliness are often driven by a sense of disconnection in our relationships rather than an absolute lack of people around us. It's common to long for genuine understanding and connection when we're feeling vulnerable or going through challenging times. I recommend expressing your feelings to those closest to you, letting them know how you're feeling and what you need from them to feel supported. It's also worth exploring the possibility of seeking out professional help, like a therapist, who can offer you a listening, non-judgmental, and understanding ear, and help you develop skills to build deeper connections in your relationships. Remember, it's okay to ask for what you need and to be open about expressing your feelings. I believe in your ability to build stronger connections and overcome feelings of loneliness.

I understand that you feel stuck in a relationship where you are not getting the emotional connection and presence that you desire. It's important to recognize that everyone has different relationship needs and expectations. In your case, it appears that you are seeking a more frequent and intensive connection than what your current partner is able to provide due to geographical and time constraints.  Your fear of being alone and the anxiety of losing this relationship can make the thought of ending it daunting. It's normal to feel a sense of loss and uncertainty when contemplating a separation, but it's also essential to consider if the relationship aligns with your long-term goals and emotional well-being.  You mentioned that you have felt this way several times before and have reconciled due to anxiety and depression. This cycle can be detrimental to your emotional health and can potentially hinder your ability to find and pursue a healthier, more fulfilling relationship.  If you believe that ending the relationship is the best course of action for your emotional growth, it's recommended that you take the following steps:  1. Be clear with yourself about your relationship priorities and expectations. 2. Communicate your feelings to your partner in a calm and compassionate manner. 3. Prepare emotionally for the possible end of the relationship, understanding that it may involve some sadness and loss, and trust that you will be able to move through it. 4. Focus on your personal growth, and practice self-care and self-love during this transition. 5. Consider joining a support group or seeking a therapist to help process your emotions.  Ultimately, the decision to end the relationship is a personal one, and it's essential to trust your intuition and do what's best for your emotional health. Remember, it's okay to prioritize your emotional needs and search for a connection that feels more fulfilling and present in your life.

I am so very sorry for how pressured and sad you feel right now.Definitely all family members have an effect on the other ones.From what you write, your family members are not considering the effect their negative comments have on you.Also, keep in mind that each person is responsible for deciding to argue or find a different way to discuss a problem. You are not in control of the other people in your family.More likely they take the easy way out and blame you for what they don't want to know about themselves.Stay aware that the family's decision to target you doesn't mean that you are doing something wrong.   Certainly your existence is not wrong, which is the degree to which the unfairness seems to have spread.What to do about it is read about family systems to see more explanations on how you are being unfairly treated.Also stay in touch with friends bc these are the people who value and respect you.

The comments here from the other therapists are "spot on". As a Certified Sex Addiction Therapist-Candidate I'm convinced your partner's acting out creates trauma for you. Your partner's addiction is NOT your fault and his recovery IS his responsibility. What's paramount is for you to get immediate help from an experienced therapist who understands trauma as result of the partner's/spouse's problematic sexual behaviors. Your needs, safety, and the establishment of reasonable boundaries is vital to your well-being. I wish you the very best.Resources for Your Consideration: 1) https://www.iitap.com/, 2) https://www.sanon.org/, 3) http://www.cosa-recovery.org/

I'm sorry for your loss and the pain you've held onto for so long. Grieving the loss of a parent, especially at a young age, can be extremely difficult. It's normal to feel overwhelmed, but it's crucial to understand that it's okay to ask for help. You mentioned that you can't handle it anymore, and that's a clear indication that you need support.  There are various ways to seek help, such as talking to a trusted friend or family member, joining a support group, or seeking professional help from a mental health professional like myself. We can explore different therapeutic approaches, like cognitive-behavioral therapy, to help you manage your emotions and work through your grief. Remember, it's essential to take care of yourself and allow yourself to heal in a healthy and supportive manner.

Or...better yet... Is it you still thinking about the other girl?  I am sure his cheating hurt you emotionally and may have affected your sexual performance as well.  Make sure the other girl is out the picture on your end as well.  Sounds like something the both of you need to have a calm and adult conversation about.

I understand your concerns about everyday stressors. It's not uncommon to feel anxious about financial pressures, work demands, personal relationships, and family responsibilities. It's important to recognize that these feelings are normal to some extent, but when they interfere with your daily functioning, it may be helpful to consider some coping strategies.  First, try to prioritize your tasks and focus on what's most important. Breaking larger tasks into smaller, manageable steps can make them seem more manageable. Delegating tasks to others when possible can also reduce your stress.  Second, practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation. These practices can help reduce anxiety and improve overall well-being.  Third, it may be helpful to seek support from friends, family, or a mental health professional. Sometimes, just talking about your concerns can help alleviate some of the pressure.  Lastly, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, proper nutrition, and sufficient sleep can improve your resilience to stressors. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and take care of yourself. Would you like me to suggest any specific resources or refer you to a mental health professional?

I understand your situation can be difficult and complex, but it's essential for your well-being and your son's sake to prioritize your safety and emotional health. Here are some suggestions:  1. Reach out for support: Connection with supportive friends, family or professionals can help ease the burden of dealing with the situation alone. Consider joining a support group or seeking counseling.  2. Identify unhealthy patterns: Recognize how past experiences may be contributing to your current behavior in relationships. Understanding these patterns can help you break the cycle and make healthier choices moving forward.  3. Safe environment for your son: Ensure your son's safety is a top priority. If you feel threatened, consider reaching out to law enforcement or a domestic violence shelter for help.  4. Self-care: Focus on your mental, emotional and physical wellbeing. Engage in activities you enjoy, practice relaxation techniques, and invest time in activities that nourish your soul.  5. Set healthy boundaries: Be clear with your partner about what you will and will not tolerate in your relationship. If he is unwilling to change his behaviors, it may be best to end the relationship for the sake of both yourself and your son.  Remember, healing takes time and patience, and it is essential to prioritize your own wellbeing over staying in an abusive or unhealthy relationship.

I understand that you're going through a difficult time, and it's important to prioritize your emotional well-being. Lying to your partner, even about what might seem trivial, can cause mistrust and negatively impact the relationship. The fact that your husband's response includes verbal and emotional abuse is concerning and is not a healthy way for a partner to behave. These behaviors can create a toxic environment for you and your child.  It's crucial that you communicate openly and honestly with your husband about this issue. Express how his response has made you feel and how you'd like to work on rebuilding trust in your relationship. This might involve seeking couples counseling to help facilitate effective communication.  Ultimately, it's up to you to decide if this relationship is worth continuing. If your husband does not make an effort to work on improving their response and behavior towards you, it may be time to consider moving on for both your and your child's well-being. Remember that your emotional safety is essential, regardless of any shared responsibilities you have.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult situation. It's important to remember that your worth and happiness aren't determined by a relationship or any one person. Abuse, emotional or verbal, is not acceptable in a healthy relationship. You have the right to prioritize your emotional and physical wellbeing.  To leave this toxic relationship, first, create a safety plan. Identify people you can reach out to for support, and consider seeking professional help. As you build your confidence and prepare to leave, start making small changes, like setting boundaries with your boyfriend, or establishing your own routine that doesn't involve him.  Eventually, if you feel ready, consider formally ending the relationship. Remember, it takes time to heal, so be patient with yourself through this process. Remember, you deserve to be in a healthy, loving, and respectful relationship.

Although I am not entirely sure why you might be struggling in this area, an initial question I have is do you want to be sexually active at this time or is this something that you feel pressured into doing.?  If you feel pressured into being sexually active by your friends or boyfriend it is understandable that you want it to be over.  I would encourage you to ask your boyfriend to be patient with you at this time  until you figure out what is going on.  I encourage you to then think very deeply about what your reservations, if any,  about being sexually active.  Do you fear pregnancy?  Are there problems in the relationship?  Are you afraid of the emotional intimacy? Another question that comes to mind is whether or not you have any history of sexual activity that you did not consent to that might be getting in the way.   When these types of traumatic events occur,  people can essentially become triggered negatively by anything that reminds them of past trauma.  Such events can cause an aversion to sex even if there is now a loving relationship whom one wants to be sexually active with.  If this is the case I strongly recommend individual therapy to begin working through some of these issues. A final area that you might explore would be whether or not you are experiencing pain with penetration.  If so, I would recommend that you schedule an appointment with a gynecologist to rule out any type of medical issues that might be causing these problems.  Although pain can also be associated with emotional issues, it is always good to rule out possible physical causes.  I hope that these ideas help to point you in the right direction.  Take care.

I understand that you are experiencing a significant personal issue and seeking guidance. Gender identity exploration and transition are complex processes that involve emotional, social, and medical aspects. Here are some suggestions:  1. Self-education: Read up on transgender issues to gain a better understanding of the experiences and challenges related to gender identity. There are numerous resources on the internet, books, and organizations dedicated to this topic.  2. Support and community: Connect with other transgender individuals or support groups to learn from their experiences and find companionship. This can provide valuable insight and alleviate feelings of isolation.  3. Therapy: Consider scheduling an appointment with a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or counselor, who specializes in gender identity issues. They can help you evaluate your needs, explore your identity further, and provide resources.  4. Physical changes: Consult with medical specialists, such as endocrinologists or surgeons, who specialize in gender affirming hormonal therapies and surgeries. Keep in mind that these treatments can be costly, time-consuming, and may not be covered by your insurance.  5. Legal and social considerations: Be aware of the social, legal, and cultural implications associated with your gender identity. Determine if you will need to make any changes to your identity documents or workplace policies.  Remember, embarking on this journey is a deeply personal experience, and it is essential to take your time and make informed decisions that are best for your overall wellbeing. Best wishes on your journey to explore and affirm your true self.

How is your boyfriend responding to your discomfort around him?Has he told you that he's noticed changes in you?The good news about a relationship is that you can talk about matters with the other person.  Doing so can only help clarify feelings and what either of you expect from the relationship.  Given that the two of you recently moved in together, it is natural for new dynamics, feelings and expectations to arise.  It just adds to the reasonableness of talking with each other about how living together feels to each of you.Psychiatrists earn their living by diagnosing people and telling them to take pills.  Very often, just being told the person has a "condition" makes them feel fragile and less capable than they actually are.Anxiety and panic attacks do mean that there is a great deal of emotion and situation needing to be addressed.It is the normal sign of having to address many or deep matters.   Be patient and give yourself time to learn the details of your relationship and whatever the career particulars are that are bothering you.   You're apparently self-aware since you're the one describing your own problematic situations.  Keep the label of being "disordered", aside.  Psychiatry labels do more good for psychiatrists than they do for people who are trying to live their lives.

Any diagnosis is limited in its usefulness.Knowing the name of some typical ways you may feel, think and behave, doesn't help you or anyone to understand why the person is the way they are and how to change any of these characteristics.Both self-diagnosing and being diagnosed are equally unhelpful to know why you are the way you are and what to do about it.Consider yourself a person who wants to find a better way to be who you are, and this will get you further with better results than to read a list of descriptions which all are very indicting and negative sounding.

Sorry for you and sorry for the cat because you're each in a tense position.What was the context of your boyfriend adopting a cat since he was aware that this would likely cause problems in the relationship with you?If you don't already know his answer, then find out.  Doing so will tell you a lot about your boyfriend's expectations about you.  Does he expect you to accept without question, whatever he does?  Does he care about your views?  Does a cat have some deep meaning for him that having one is essential to his life and he never told you so?Please don't be mean to the cat.  Its not the cat's fault for being in your boyfriend's care.There are plenty of other cats on this earth so throwing out the cat will not solve anything between you and your boyfriend.Who knows, your boyfriend may come back home with three more cats!Start with a conversation about your feelings and his interest in your feelings.

I'm really sorry to hear about the difficult situation you're in. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of emotional pain and fear, especially with your stepdaughter's overdose and your daughter's blame towards you. It's important to recognize that addiction is a complex issue, and it's not the fault of any one person. However, it's normal for family members to feel overwhelmed and unsure of what to do when dealing with a loved one's addiction.  Given your health condition, it's essential to prioritize your own well-being. It's not uncommon for family members, especially those who are caretakers, to feel blamed or burdened by their loved ones' addictions. But it's crucial to remember that you cannot control their choices, only your reactions to them.  Regarding your children's blame towards you, it's essential to understand that addiction can provoke strong emotions, including anger, sadness, and blame, and these feelings can sometimes be misdirected towards loved ones, including parents. However, it's vital to maintain open and honest communication with them, expressing your concerns and feelings while also acknowledging theirs.  In these situations, it's also important to seek out resources and support networks for yourself. Consider joining a support group for families dealing with addiction, such as Al-Anon or Nar-Anon. These groups can provide valuable insights, guidance, and a sense of community for those dealing with the challenging circumstances of a loved one's addiction.  Moreover, you might find it helpful to speak with a mental health professional, who can help you navigate the emotional turmoil you're experiencing and provide coping strategies to manage the stress and fear related to your children's addiction. Remember that self-care is essential, particularly in stressful situations like these.  Lastly, consider reaching out to trusted friends, family, or professionals to help you take care of daily tasks and errands if needed. This can free up some time and energy for you to focus on your emotional and mental well-being, as well as maintaining a strong support system to help you through this challenging time.

Well Boise, the cat's out of the bag now, isn't it? I love that you want to help your kids keep the magic of Christmas. They must want that too if they still believe in Santa into their teen years, which is unusual, I believe. I wonder if they had already figured it out anyway?But they know now, and your ex had the right to tell them if he felt it was best. So it's time to explain to them what a loving and magical thing it is that parents do, and Christmas can still be magical in so many ways. Really, who says they have to stop believing in Santa? Santa is very real as a spirit of surprise, generosity and love.

There are various reasons why some individuals may be attracted to older men. Here are some possibilities:  1. Life experience: Older men may have more life experience, which can make them seem more mature and stable. They may have a greater understanding of the world and relationships, which can be attractive to some people. 2. Security: Older men may offer a sense of security and stability, particularly if they are established in their careers and financially secure. 3. Emotional connection: Some people may find that older men provide a deeper emotional connection, as they may be more emotionally expressive or more attuned to their partner's needs. 4. Familiarity: Growing up with older brothers or older male figures in their lives can make some people attracted to older men as adults.  However, it's important to remember that everyone is different and there is no one-size-fits-all explanation for why people are attracted to certain types of people. Your attraction to older men is valid and normal, regardless of the reason.  It's also important to ensure that any relationship you have is healthy and consensual. If you're worried about your attraction or have any concerns about relationships or your sexuality, it may be helpful to speak to a mental health professional for guidance and support.

Hi Jayuya, I'm struggling in this moment with my own biases. I have biases that are about respect and every individual's need for and right to respect. Your husband lies, cheats and physically hurts you. He makes excuses and blames you for these behaviours and trains you to do the same. He demonstrates many controlling and abusive behaviours. And now, in an attempt to manipulate and silence you, he wants to have his cake and eat it too and suggests you should share him? There aren't many crumbs of this cake left for you, are there?So, my biases about respect don't make me want to rescue you or tell you what to do; I can't do that, and I don't think either of those things will help you. I'd like to ask you some questions though...Are you happy? Do you know what happy is? Do you know what respect is? Are your children safe? Are your children witnessing violence (because if they are, then they're not safe)? Do you have supports? Do your family and friends know what's happening in your life? Have you ever been to a women's shelter? Are you willing to sit down in an office with a professional who can help you think clearly? That's what I suggest. These are big decisions, you deserve some support. I wish you the best.

If you're in a relationship and you're having strong thoughts about someone else, it's important to pay attention to that. Although you say you're happy, I'd suggest looking really carefully at the relationship you have and whether you're getting everything you need. Is there a physical connection with your ex that you don't have with your current boyfriend? It could be that your boyfriend is marvelous in many areas, but that you just don't feel excited about him for some reason. That's a pretty important element to be missing.It may be that, even if you are happy with your current boyfriend, you still hold something special for your ex. If you feel the need to see what is possible there, I think you have to tell your boyfriend about that and end it with him first. You can't have everything.If you truly feel that you want to be with your current boyfriend, you will do well to stop thinking about and focusing on your ex, because thoughts of him will interfere with the growth of your current relationship. The grass isn't greener... A therapist can help you to focus your energies and thoughts on the present, rather than an imagined version of the past or future.

Is it possible you simply didn't mix well with the particular therapists with whom you've worked?   If this is possible, interview a therapist before  starting therapy.   Then you will be choosing a therapist who feels compatible with your way of seeing yourself and your life.Also, therapy isn't for everyone.Read about the different healing modalities and see if one of these speaks to your interest in feeling better.What matters most is finding among all the legitimate healing methods, what you believe will be effective.

There are an infinite number of ways to look at this. Spirituality, religion, God, higher power, and many other parts of this discussion mean different things to different people. My question for you is what does "real" actually mean to you? Often, the concept of God has to do with what you believe in. If you ask 1000 different people, you'll probably get almost that many different answers.Consider talking with friends or family about this. I would suggest, though, that you have the discussion initially with people who you trust and who you feel are willing to listen to your questions and beliefs and perhaps offer an opinion without trying to make you believe as they do. You may also consider speaking with a pastor or another religious figure. The local Salvation Army may have a link to a religious or spiritual person that leads nondenominational church services. There may be able to help you to sort through this if your friends and family do not provide a comfortable environment for you related to this discussion.Just a word of caution. In my experience, ideas of religion and spirituality can be lead to very deep discussions with some people who are very strongly connected to what they believe. Some people do not easily separate their own beliefs from those of others. When initiating conversations about this, try first asking whether someone would be comfortable discussing religion or spirituality. A second question may be whether it is okay with this person you are talking to if you have different beliefs or opinions.As far as whether God is real or not, consider trusting yourself and what you learn, feel, and believe as you work through this process.

It's important to recognize that depression is not solely defined by feelings of sadness. Depression can manifest in many ways, including apathy, loss of interest in activities, and feelings of hopelessness or emptiness, among other symptoms. While it's understandable that you may be unsure, it can be helpful to explore these feelings further with a mental health professional. A trained therapist or psychiatrist can help you understand your symptoms and make an accurate diagnosis, as well as provide you with effective treatment options if needed. So, it wouldn't be a bad idea to consider reaching out to a mental health professional for an evaluation. This can give you a clearer sense of where you stand and help you take the next steps if necessary.

Does anyone notice that you get sick and cry on track meet days?Have you told anyone?From what you write, as much as you would like to please your school and dad, something within you doesn't quite want to fully follow through.Step one in life always is to know what you want and what your limits are.   It already is difficult to avoid listening to your body.Try understanding what is difficult in telling your father that you'd like doing as he wishes, only are not able to do so because you are emotionally and physically distraught on the days you have track.After finishing the season for this year with your school's track team, then expect to concentrate on taking care of your own need to not do track.Hopefully your father will understand and care about your problem.   If he does not and track is more important than your well being, then you have a different problem entirely.

I understand your situation, and it's common for relationships to involve complex emotions and difficult decisions. Based on the information provided, it seems you've weighed the pros and cons of getting back together with this person. It's important to remember that only you can decide what feels right for you. Here are a few things to consider:  1. Why did you break up in the first place? If the issues that led to the break-up are still present, it may be wise to reconsider. 2. Have you really forgiven him, or have you just given him another chance out of habit or convenience? It's crucial that any healing be genuine and authentic. 3. What does your instinct tell you? Pay attention to your intuition, as it can be a reliable indicator of emotional well-being. 4. How will getting back together impact your mental and emotional health? Is it a positive step forward, or is it potentially detrimental? 5. What's the potential cost of getting involved again? Are you prepared for the possibility of heartbreak or disappointment? 6. What do other people in your support system think? Their perspective might offer valuable insight and advice. 7. What if things don't work out this time? Do you have a backup plan?  Reflect on these questions and consider seeking advice from a trusted friend, family member, or mental health professional for additional guidance. Remember, it's essential to make decisions based on your well-being and happiness rather than other people's opinions.

Do you have a close friend or relative who's opinion you trust? Ask them for their honest feedback and if they see you like your cousin does. If they don’t see these qualities in you, then it may be your cousin’s issue and she’s taking it out on you. You can always ask her what would be the best way to communicate plans with her so you know, specifically, what she is expecting. Then if you meet these expectations and she still blames you and comments on how inconsiderate you are, it's her issue and she is not coming from a place of love.Even if you do resemble her comments, the way it sounds like she approaches this problem is not out of love. The fact that you're introspective enough to consider your own behavior suggests the problem is not with you.

I'm sorry for what you've been through, and it's understandable that you continue to experience distressing symptoms even after seven years. Nightmares related to past traumatic events are common, and they can feel very real and vivid. However, I want to reassure you that you're not alone, and there are effective treatments for distressing symptoms like nightmares.  One effective approach is Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR). EMDR is a psychotherapy that was originally designed to alleviate the distress of traumatic memories. The therapy involves the use of bilateral stimulation, which is a type of sensory input, to help reduce the emotional intensity of the traumatic memories. Research suggests that this approach can help alleviate symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), including nightmares.  Another effective approach is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT is a type of psychotherapy that can help you learn skills to manage your symptoms and change negative thought patterns. One specific approach within CBT, calledimaginal exposure, may be helpful in reducing nightmares. Imaginal exposure involves visualizing the traumatic event in your mind while you're awake and in a safe environment, with the goal of reducing the emotional intensity and fear associated with the event.  You might also find it helpful to practice relaxation techniques before bed, such as deep breathing or Progressive Muscle Relaxation, to help reduce your overall stress and anxiety levels. Additionally, avoid using electronic devices, such as smartphones and laptops, right before bedtime, as the blue light emitted by these devices can disrupt your sleep.  Lastly, consider reaching out to support groups or organizations that provide resources and counseling for victims of domestic violence. They can offer a safe and supportive environment where you can connect with others who have similar experiences.  If you're interested in pursuing any of these approaches or have further questions, please let me know. I can refer you to resources in your area, or help you find a mental health provider who specializes in trauma and PTSD.

If you thing your trust issues are going to end or affect your relationship it will because you are being baggage from your parents into this relationship.  Don't allow their problems to become your problem.  You didn't mention that your partner in your present relationship have done anything to make you not trust them.  Like in the court of law, if no evidence....find not guilty.  Don't make them pay the consequences as if guilty of your parents unhealthy behavior.

I understand that letting go of a deeply felt love can be incredibly challenging, especially when it feels unique or extraordinary. It's important to acknowledge that the intensity of feelings may fade over time, even if the memory of the experience remains.  To help move forward, you might consider focusing on the following:  1. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that make you happy and relaxed. Eat well, exercise, and ensure you have enough sleep.  2. Reconnect with previous interests: Re-establish connections with hobbies, friends, or activities that you may have neglected during your relationship.  3. Write about your emotions: Journaling can be an effective tool for processing complex emotions.  4. Seek out supportive relationships: Share your feelings with trusted individuals, such as a therapist or supportive friend.  5. Adopt a growth mindset: Use this experience as an opportunity to learn and grow as a person.  Remember, healing takes time – be patient and compassionate with yourself. Additionally, recognize that there is no "wrong" way to experience or process love. It's important to prioritize your own emotional and mental wellbeing.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, but I can't provide you with the help that you need through this text-based interaction. It's important to remember that everyone has their unique beauty and worth. The fact that some men may only be interested in a physical relationship with you doesn't mean that you're unworthy of love and respect in all aspects. Focusing on physical attributes like stretch marks is not an accurate or fair reflection of one's worth. I recommend reaching out to a mental health professional, therapist, or counselor, who can provide you with the tools and support you need to work through your feelings of depression and low self-worth. They can help you develop healthy coping mechanisms and challenge negative thought patterns. Additionally, talking to a trusted friend or family member about how you're feeling might be helpful. Remember, it's okay to ask for help, and seeking it out is a courageous step towards improving your emotional well-being.

Philadelphia, there is help out there. For your daughter's sake, start somewhere. Feelings are only that; your worst fears about who you are are only based on a few moments that haven't gone well. Depression is so treatable, but you have to seek treatment from a professional.Here's a quick exercise for you to do that can show you how therapy might work... fear is telling you the worst possible story of your life, right? So... if there was an opposite story...the very best story that someone could tell about you and your life...what would that be? Who would be telling it? Someone who loves you? Someone who was around you when you were that outgoing person? Someone who's been watching your life from the start? God? Write that best story. I dare you to give it as much credibility as the worst one. Therapy is often about helping people reject their "worst stories". I invite you to start exploring with a qualified therapist whatever barriers stand between you and your best life. I hope you reach out soon. :)

You might be surprised how normal you are. Anxiety is incredibly common and while your particular type of existential anxiety might be unique to you - it is very difficult for most people to really comprehend what happens after we die - regardless of the religious or philosophical belief systems we hold. It is the ultimate unknown and some philosophers and psychologists believe that at the root of our day-to-day anxieties is the fear of death or fear of the unknown.  Just as it can be really hard to comprehend the ending of life it can also be hard to comprehend an eternal existence. What these both have in common is that we are imaging a future that is ultimately unknowable and this unknown can provoke a lot of anxiety. Mindfulness based practices like meditation - maybe there is something like this in your religious tradition - can be very helpful in making peace with the unknown in the present moment. The more we can learn to live in the moment - the less we get hung up on anticipating outcomes for our lives that may never come true. Mindfulness practices can help you ground, be where you are , relax and regulate your nervous system so that you are able sleep and recuperate, and train your attention to focus on living the life you want to live now - rather than worrying about what happens after you die. Having said all that - it can be profoundly helpful to speak with someone about your anxiety - especially when you feel haunted by it, worry that you are crazy and can't get to sleep. There are lots of good therapists out there who can help you with your anxiety.

I understand that your relationship dynamics have shifted, and it is causing you concern. It is essential to have open and honest communication about your feelings and needs with your partner. Express your concerns to him when you both have ample time to talk and listen to each other without feeling defensive. It might be helpful to explore the possibility of setting aside dedicated time for each other, perhaps through scheduling regular dates or setting aside specific hours for undivided attention. Additionally, considering the role of outside influences, such as his demanding work and athletic commitments, could be discussed, potentially leading to solutions that accommodate both of your needs. If the issue persists, seeking the help of a couples therapist may offer further insight and guidance.

I'm so sorry to hear that you are going through this difficult experience with your father's drug use and the resulting impact on family dynamics. It's important to remember that you are not responsible for someone else's substance abuse, and it's okay to prioritize your own health and safety. These situations can indeed cause anger, stress, and other negative emotions, but I encourage you to seek out healthy coping mechanisms such as talking to a trusted adult, engaging in physical activity, or practicing relaxation techniques. Additionally, it might be helpful to find support from others who have gone through similar experiences. Remember, it's okay to feel these emotions, but also consider reaching out to a mental health professional to talk through things further and develop additional coping strategies.

I imagine you are trying to figure out a way to be "fair" to your adult kids.  The key word is "adult".  If your daughter can afford to join the family for a vacation that's great, she's welcome to come.  However, as you pointed out she took a vacation by herself last year - she chose to put her resources (time off work and money) into doing that.  Good for her - she did what she wanted.  If she wants to budget time and money for a family vacation she will.As for feeling guilty, let me echo the sentiments already offered - vacations are lovely, but not a survival need.  Your girl is in her 20s and it's her turn to provide for herself.  You did your parenting - now go enjoy your vacation with whoever can, and wants to, join you!

As a psychologist, I cannot provide a definitive answer without knowing the specific employment laws in your location. However, generally speaking, an employer cannot force you to see a therapist of their choice against your will. Employers can only require employees to undergo a medical examination when it is job-related and consistent with business necessity. In the case of your coworkers' allegations, if they rise to the level of creating a hostile work environment or affecting your ability to perform your job duties, then you may want to consider speaking with a human resources representative or consulting an employment lawyer for guidance. If mental health concerns are impacting your work, I would recommend seeking mental health treatment voluntarily as a beneficial step for your overall wellbeing. Confidentiality and options for affordable or covered therapy can be discussed with your healthcare provider and/or insurance company.

Hi Texas, Thanks for your honesty; it helps me know where to go in answering you. What strikes me in your question is that you describe several ways in which your husband is hurtful/abusive/controlling with you, and then you ask "Should we call it quits?". We? I wonder if maybe the first step is for you to start seeing this decision as yours, rather than yours together. The way your husband treats you is not your fault, Texas. Your lies are a natural and normal way of you avoiding situations and encounters that feel unsafe for you. The problem is not your lying. The problem is that you don't feel safe enough to be honest with a person you're supposed to be able to trust.There's an analogy that I sometimes use; I don't know if this is scientifically true or simply a useful story, but it's powerful either way, so I will tell it to you.If you take a frog and drop it into a pot of boiling water, the frog will jump out immediately, knowing instinctively that if it stays in the pot, it will die. If you take a frog, however, and put it in a pot of cold water, and slowly, slowly, heat it to boiling, the frog will boil to death because it will fail to recognise the moment when it no longer has the energy to jump out of the pot; by the time it realises it's dying, it has lost its strength. It's called "learned helplessness". When your power or your voice has been taken away for a long time, you get used to that, and you fail to see the options that are available to you. You have a toddler, and you may be under the impression that staying in the marriage is best for the child. In my experience, and what research backs up, is that children first and foremost need a safe environment and parents who are happy. You are likely underestimating the effects on your child of living in a home with woman abuse. This is a complex picture, and if you were my client, I would want to get you to a stronger place emotionally where you're seeing the situation clearly and gathering resources and supports before you make any big decisions, but I do see that there are decisions that are there for you to make that can lead to a happy life for you and your child. I sincerely hope you seek professional help, with either a shelter for abused women or a therapist. I wish you the best.

I understand that this situation is causing you distress, as you feel that you're putting in a lot of effort but not receiving the same trust or understanding from your boyfriend. This dynamic can be challenging, and it is essential to address the underlying issues. It seems that you both have different needs and desires, and finding a compromise may be difficult.  First, it's important to communicate openly and honestly with your partner about how you feel. Express the hurt and frustration that comes from feeling untrusted and misunderstood. Also, share your fears, concerns, and needs, as well as your hopes for the relationship.  Second, you may consider couples therapy to work on the underlying issues in a safe and guided environment. A therapist can help you identify the sources of mistrust and negotiate compromises that work for both partners.  Lastly, it's crucial to remember that building and maintaining trust is a two-way street. Both partners need to make efforts to communicate, listen, respect each other's boundaries, and work towards finding solutions that meet both of their needs. If your relationship is truly worth saving, consider these steps to build a stronger foundation of trust and communication.

I see. It sounds like your partner is engaging in behavior that is leaving you feeling uncertain about the nature of your relationship. Based on the information you have provided, it may be helpful to consider having a direct conversation with your partner about your feelings and your expectations for the relationship. This is an important step in promoting open and effective communication and in understanding each other's needs and boundaries. Remember that it's normal for relationships to have ups and downs, but consistent patterns of behavior that undermine trust and create doubt may require deeper exploration and discussions. As a psychologist, I would encourage you to take care of yourself during this time, and consider reaching out to a trusted friend or therapist for support as you navigate this situation.

I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I can't provide you with the help that you need through text. Self-harm is a serious issue that requires immediate attention from a mental health professional. Please reach out to a trusted healthcare provider or call a suicide hotline, such as the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (1-800-273-8255) in the United States. They can provide you with the support and resources you need to help you through this difficult time. Remember, help is available and there are people who care about you and want to support you.

I understand that you're experiencing a lack of emotional responsiveness and feeling primarily anxious. This could be due to various reasons, such as ongoing stressors, underlying mental health conditions, or even physiological factors. It's essential to acknowledge your feelings and not dismiss the anxiety. This can be a challenging experience, and I encourage you to prioritize self-care.  Make an effort to identify potential triggers and learn mechanisms to manage your anxiety. Simple practices like deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can be helpful. Consider engaging in enjoyable activities or hobbies that bring you joy and help take your mind off anxiety. Remember that seeking professional help is a sign of strength and a step towards improving your emotional wellbeing.  Patient: I've been experiencing this for months and can't seem to shake it.  Psychologist: Consistently experiencing emotional numbness and anxiety for extended periods can indeed be debilitating, not only affecting your emotional wellbeing but also impacting your daily life and personal relationships. In these cases, considering professional help from a mental health specialist, such as a psychologist or psychiatrist, can help in diagnosing any underlying conditions and developing a comprehensive coping strategy tailored to your specific needs.  Learning new strategies and approaches can help in managing and eventually reducing your anxiety and facilitate emotional responsiveness, allowing you to fully engage in life and enhance your overall wellbeing.

While I appreciate your initiative in learning about psychological conditions, self-diagnosis, especially when it comes to complex conditions like depression, anxiety, Misophonia, Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD), and Avoidant Personality Disorder (AvPD), is not recommended. These conditions require thorough assessment and evaluation by a qualified mental health professional.  Misdiagnosis or misinterpretation of symptoms can lead to inappropriate or ineffective treatment approaches and potentially worsen the situation. Furthermore, many mental health conditions involve a lot of nuance that is hard to accurately self-assess.  It's important to remember that being knowledgeable about conditions is different from diagnosing oneself or others. Instead, I would encourage you to focus on taking the steps necessary to get a proper evaluation from a qualified mental health professional. This could involve setting up an appointment with a therapist, psychiatrist, or other healthcare provider. They will utilize their extensive knowledge, experience, and diagnostic tools to help you receive an accurate and appropriate diagnosis.  Once you have a clear understanding of your conditions, you can then collaborate with your healthcare provider to develop a tailored treatment plan that is best suited for your needs.

Patient, it is natural to feel attacked when we are in an argument, especially when it seems everyone is against us. However, it is important to take a step back and assess the situation objectively. You mention that you might be the one being unreasonable in this argument. Reflect on your behavior in the argument. Were you listening to your friends' points of view? Were you being open to compromise or were you insisting on your perspective only?  If you find that you may have been the one who escalated the situation, then it would be useful to apologize to your friends for your part in the argument. On the other hand, if your friends truly are being insensitive towards you, it would be helpful to communicate this to them in a calm and assertive manner. Try to focus on the specific behaviors that are bothering you rather than making generalizations about their attitude towards you.  Remember, effective communication is key in any relationship and requires active listening, empathy, and respect for each other's viewpoints. I hope this helps, Patient. Let me know if you have any further questions or need additional clarification.

I can understand how difficult and painful it is for you to deal with your wife's emotional distress and the threats of infidelity, especially during this time of year which might be a trigger for her due to the memories of losing your first born child.  It's important for both you and your wife to acknowledge that the grief she experiences is complex and deeply rooted. It may be helpful for her to seek professional counseling to help her process her emotions and work through her feelings of loss in a healthy and productive manner.  In your case, it might be essential for you to focus on your own emotional healing, as well, by working on your coping mechanisms, such as reaching out to friends, seeking therapy for yourself, and engaging in self-care activities. It's also crucial that you communicate openly and honestly with your wife about your feelings and your expectations.  Keep in mind that making things right between you won't happen overnight, so it's essential to be patient, stay committed, and have realistic expectations. Consider consulting a professional counselor or therapist who specializes in couples therapy to develop effective strategies for managing your situation and addressing the underlying issues.

Based on what you've shared, it sounds like you might be experiencing a combination of typical adolescent emotional intensity and some signs of impulsivity and frustration-management difficulties. It's normal for teenagers to have strong emotions and intense mood swings. However, your behavior when these mood swings occur, particularly your irritation and blaming of others when they intervene or when things don't go as planned, could be related to anger or frustration management issues.  It might be helpful to explore some strategies for managing your emotions and responses. This could include things like taking a few deep breaths before reacting, identifying and challenging negative thoughts, and practicing empathy towards others by considering their perspective.  I would encourage you to speak with a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist, for a more thorough evaluation and personalized advice. They can help you develop coping skills and provide additional support as needed.

Hi Helena,I felt a bit sad when I read this. This is a new term for me... "semi-relationship". What does it mean? I know that today's culture for young people is more of a "hook-up" culture than a dating one. Maybe that means that you develop connections to people but you keep yourself from hoping for a full relationship because no one is doing that anymore. That makes me feel sad. I hear a lot of young women (I'm not sure you're female, but that's my guess) say that they struggle with hook-ups because they can't let themselves hope for a phone call after a hook-up. Research tells us that, after a hook-up, college age women tend to feel used and unworthy, and men tend to feel guilty. I think this scenario works better for men than women, but many of both genders are left unsatisfied in the end.This is only one possible explanation for your anxiety...that your gut knows that it wants to feel fully coupled with someone but you struggle with whether it's okay to want or expect that.Maybe take a moment and listen to anxiety. Anxiety tends to try to convince us that something's wrong with us or something bad's going to happen. Anxiety sometimes prefers to stay vague (it's more difficult to refute it then), but you can try to clarify it's whisperings by asking yourself these questions: What am I afraid of? What is the worst thing that might happen here? Then what might happen, and what would be the worst part of that? Keep going until you find the very worst thing that might happen? Might someone not want you...might you feel rejected...or feel not good enough...you might get hurt?Then when you find that core fear, you can look at your life and I bet you'd find a place where that idea or fear originated. A big moment (or many smaller ones) when you actually DID feel or get rejected or abandoned or hurt. In the end, it's a feeling you're trying to avoid (not life or relationship), and anxiety is trying to help you avoid it by making you overcautious. But this doesn't work for you! Good! With the help of a qualified therapist, you can learn to talk back to anxiety and move forward in life and love with calm. confidence.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult time after your breakup. It's natural to feel pain and loss when relationships end. Here are some steps you can take to help you move forward:  1. Give yourself time to grieve: Allow yourself to feel the emotions that come with the breakup. Avoiding or suppressing your feelings will prolong the healing process.  2. Engage in self-care: Take good care of your physical and emotional needs. Exercise regularly, eat well, get enough sleep, and do activities that you enjoy.  3. Reach out to support system: Surround yourself with positive friends and family. They can provide you with encouragement and a fresh perspective.  4. Focus on personal growth: Use this experience as an opportunity to learn and grow from the relationship. Consider therapy or self-help resources to help you work through your feelings and develop new coping skills.  5. Avoid dwelling on the past: Instead of ruminating on the negative aspects of the relationship, focus on the present and the future. Set goals for yourself and work towards creating a fulfilling life.  6. Stay away from triggers: Avoid people, places, and things that remind you of the relationship. This may include social media, mutual friends, or certain songs or memories.  7. Practice forgiveness: Holding onto anger and resentment will only prolong your suffering. Try to find forgiveness for yourself and the other person.  Remember, healing takes time, so be patient with yourself and allow the process to unfold naturally.

Congrats on having a happiness problem.Go slowly and tell your partner how you feel as you discover how being loved feels.On a deep level you’re releasing yourself from interaction patterns which treated you poorly and unkindly.Time is needed of repeated occurrences of this newfound loving behavior toward you.Gradually you will trust more and more that your new living relationship life is your reality.

There are typically three reasons why therapy is terminated:1) Client has met therapy goals2) Client is not progressing 3) Therapist is not a good fit for clientIn order to properly assess whether therapy is helping and what progress is being made, the therapist needs to have ways of consistently checking in with clients sessions-by-session to determine what is helping, what isn't, and where the client is at in relation to their original therapy goals. When a client has met their goals, that is a good time to end counselling sessions unless the client has new goals or simply wants to check-in periodically to make sure that they are still on track (sometimes referred to as relapse prevention). When a client is not progressing, and feedback has been taken and attempts have been made to make the therapy more helpful for the client but to no avail, than it is considered unethical to continue to work with the client. In these circumstances, referring out to another therapist who may be a better fit is a good idea.

I wonder if you could have a conversation with your boyfriend about how you are feeling. A few things may help with that:Try having the conversation you are both able to have a conversation about something that is important (for example, not during a commercial for a TV show)Maybe your boyfriend will be willing to listen to you for about five minutes asking questions to learn more about your experience, kind of like an investigative reporter wouldSee if your boyfriend is able to capture the essence of what you're saying by summarizing it for youRemember that hearing you and following what you're saying does not mean that he agreesAlso consider if there are events in your past that are affecting the way you are looking at this relationship between your boyfriend and this other girl (we all bring our own histories into relationships and we unconsciously expect that what has worked in other relationships will work in current ones)Then you can switch so that you can hear more about what he is experiencing (for example, what it is that he likes about her)Also consider having a discussion that if one of you becomes very emotional and needs a break from the discussion, discuss having a timeout that will last for a certain time frame (usually between 15 minutes and one hour) and then come back to continue the discussionRemember that the goal here is just to learn more about what each of you is going through, not to find a solution right awayThis can be difficult. Consider working with a couples therapist to discuss it together.

This is so very common in this crazy looks-obsessed world! I meet so many beautiful people who can't see their beauty. Is there something getting in the way for you? Was there a time in your life when people teased you or told you something hurtful, or did something to you that made you feel ugly? If so, this can be addressed first. Sometimes stories are told about us when we're young and the best thing we can do is see the author's evil or careless intent and not take that on. A therapist can help you with this part.Once you've addressed any past barriers to feeling confident, you can focus on a few simple things. First, your thoughts. If you keep telling yourself that you don't like what you see, then you will never feel okay about your looks. Experiment with telling yourself something different. Look in the mirror and I dare you to find something that's lovely about your face. Focus on that. Describe what you see? If you were your own best friend, what would you say about your face? Eliminating those negative scripts and building new positive ones will help you feel more accepting of how you look. You can't change your face, but you can change your attitude towards your face. Confidence is the things that will make you beautiful!Accepting how you look is important. Without going to plastic surgery (the popularity of which is a testimony to how nuts this whole thing has become), you were born with that nose, those eyes, those lips. Accepting yourself and knowing it won't change is a good idea, because wishing it were different won't make it so!Looking good is also about minimizing flaws and building on your assets. Are you in a rut about hairstyle or makeup? Ask a good friend to give you a make-over. Play with your features and wardrobe. There are plenty of average looking people who know how to make themselves shine because they are creative!

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult time in your marriage. It's understandable for you to feel hurt and confused by your husband's words. However, it's important to remember that relationships are complex and dynamic. People grow and change over time, and sometimes, we encounter challenging situations that require us to communicate openly and honestly about our feelings and needs.  Your husband's statement about not being in love with you may have been painful, but it doesn't necessarily mean that he doesn't value or care for you. It may be an indication that there are unmet needs or unresolved issues in your relationship that need to be addressed.  I'd recommend approaching this situation with a mindset of curiosity rather than judgment. Try to communicate with your husband about how you're feeling, and ask him to share his thoughts and feelings as well. Be open to the possibility that there may be things that you can work on together to strengthen your relationship.  It's also essential to prioritize your self-care during this time. Engage in activities that bring you joy and help you feel good about yourself. Seek support from trusted friends, family, or a mental health professional if needed.  Remember, it's important not to define your worth solely based on your relationship with your husband. You are a valuable and complex person with many qualities and abilities that make you unique. Consider focusing on the qualities that make you feel good about yourself, rather than dwelling on hurtful words.  Ultimately, relationships require effort and commitment from both parties. If you're willing to work on the relationship and communicate openly, it might be worth considering couples therapy to help you navigate this challenging time. Good luck.

I understand how distressing it is to experience frequent nightmares that disrupt your sleep and affect your daily life. Nightmares are not uncommon, and they can be caused by various factors such as stress, anxiety, trauma, certain medications, and certain health conditions. Here are some steps you can take to potentially reduce the frequency and intensity of your nightmares: 1. Reduce stress: Try to manage stress through relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation. Make sure you are getting enough sleep, eating healthy, and engaging in regular physical activity. 2. Avoid stimulants: Try to avoid stimulants such as caffeine, nicotine, and alcohol, especially in the evening, as they can disrupt your sleep and make your nightmares worse. 3. Establish a regular sleep schedule: Going to bed and waking up at the same time each day can help regulate your sleep patterns and reduce nightmares. 4. Practice good sleep hygiene: Create a comfortable sleep environment by keeping your bedroom cool, dark, and quiet. Avoid using electronic devices before bedtime as they can disrupt your sleep. 5. Write down your nightmares: Keeping a record of your nightmares can help you identify any patterns or triggers. It can also be helpful to write about them as a way of processing them and reducing their emotional impact. 6. Consider therapy: If your nightmares are caused by underlying emotional issues, such as trauma or anxiety, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. Therapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy or psychodynamic therapy, can help you understand and address the underlying causes of your nightmares. 7. Consider medication: If your nightmares are severe and impacting your daily life significantly, your doctor may recommend medication to help reduce their frequency and intensity. However, medication should be considered a last resort, as it may not address the underlying causes of the nightmares and can have side effects. Remember, it's important to talk to your healthcare provider about your nightmares if they are frequent, intense, or affecting your daily life. They can help you determine the underlying causes and recommend appropriate treatment options.

Teenagers are prone to mood swings due to developmental and hormonal changes that are rapidly and intensely occurring in your body and mind - so some of this happens to many people in your stage of development. You are not at all alone.You've taken the first and very important step in regulating your moods by just identifying that you are having these intense changes instead of being completely submerged in them and unaware! The more you are able to be a witness to your emotions and thoughts, the more you can learn to manage them. Your question offers several clues for strategies that you can try - for example, identify the warning signs for becoming irritated and plan a response, such as taking a deep breath, informing the person you are becoming irritated and need some space, or find a distraction temporarily like listening to music or going for a walk. Since you are aware of blaming others for things not working out, you can proactively make a personal commitment to taking ownership or personal responsibility by just thinking about it and practicing thoughts such as "I am responsible for my efforts" and "Blame is not helpful for anyone" and other thoughts that you believe and can repeat related to this insight. When you practice thinking more rational, healthy thoughts, you are actually rewiring your brain, so practice is key!

In case you feel some relief to know you're feeling the tone of our times.We live with crumbling of our values which then gives rise to insecurity everywhere.  If someone doesn't know what their values are then its difficult to do anything, and right now everyday we hear uncertainty in what used to be our basic assumptions.You're more normal for noticing and feeling stressed than if you imagine life felt fine the way it is!One road to take is to accept that there are no clear roads forward.  This means to change long term goals into shorter ones.Also, in general the more focused you can be as to your particular wishes, motivations, interests, and people about whom you care, the greater will be your sense of confidence that your personal world is as secure as it can be for right now.And, it helps too to know that nothing lasts forever, eventually all of what is up in the air will start to land in a much more clear way.

I understand that the memories of those events from your childhood are troubling for you. It's not uncommon for traumatic experiences to be repressed or for memories to be hazy, especially when one is young and still developing the ability to process such complex emotions and situations. This phenomenon is known as dissociation and is a common coping mechanism for dealing with trauma. You may find it helpful to explore your feelings about these memories with a therapist, who can offer you a safe and confidential space to process your emotions and gain a better understanding of how these experiences have affected you. Remember that it's important to be kind to yourself and acknowledge that you're doing the best you can with the resources you have.

How someone feels when they forgive another, is at peace with themselves and their understanding of what went wrong, who was responsible for what in the situation, and clarity on their own motivation, actions, emotions including pain, regret, resentment, sadness.These steps ideally allow a new door to open in order to develop new paths in the existing relationship or accept that this will not be possible due to either person's way of handling themselves.The long answer would be that you're not yet through with this process.I commend you on being truthful with yourself about yourself.You're on the right track by expecting to feel resolved when you've reached resolution, and not before.Finding patience with the unpredictable amount of time needed to thoroughly examine all the details of the incidents you mention, sometimes is a frustration of its own.Keep up your good work of knowing your own life.It is a worthwhile endeavor!

I'm sorry for your disappointment with this girl.Maybe next time you start to like someone talk with the person to find out if they feel similar to you.   This way you have a good chance to avoid being hurt in the way you describe here.Even if the person doesn't give you a straightforward answer to their feelings for you, you'll gain a little more information by listening to how seriously they consider your question, what their body language is like, whether or not the person seems sincere.Listen to your gut.If you feel unsure the person likes you as much as you like them, then wait a little while to see if your feelings about the person or their feelings about you, change and in what direction they change.Keep yourself informed as best you can so you'll know you did as much as possible to kiss someone who understands your kiss the way you mean it to be understood.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this difficult time. It's important to acknowledge that your emotions are valid, and it's normal to be concerned about someone you care about, especially in a crisis situation. however, I also understand that the constant worry can be draining and harmful to your own well-being.  It's essential that you prioritize self-care and maintain a healthy balance between your concern for your boyfriend and your own physical and emotional well-being. If your relationship is causing you more harm than good, it's worth considering seeking professional help or joining a support group for people going through similar experiences.  Ultimately, it's your decision to make, and only you can determine what is best for you. It might be helpful to speak with a mental health professional who can help you explore your options and facilitate a healthy decision-making process. Remember, it's okay to prioritize your own well-being and make choices that protect your peace of mind.

I understand that you are in a challenging situation with your mother's codependent and manipulative behavior towards you. It's important to recognize that as an adult, you have the right to prioritize your own life, relationships, and happiness. Manipulation is not a healthy way for your mother to behave towards you, and it's not sustainable for you to continue to be emotionally drained by her actions.  Your mother's diabetes is a serious condition, and I'm sure she needs support. However, her use of it as a guilt trip should not prevent you from making decisions that are best for you and your boyfriend. It's important to have open and honest communication with her about your feelings and the boundaries you need to set to ensure your emotional well-being.  You might also consider involving a professional, such as a therapist or counselor, to help facilitate these conversations and provide guidance on how to set healthy boundaries while managing the complex dynamics of your relationship with your mother.  Remember, you have the power to make decisions that are in your best interest, and prioritizing your own happiness and well-being is a necessary step towards starting a new life with your boyfriend.

A rare topic & likely extremely troublesome for you... I would need to have more background information on the two of you before beginning to offer any insight. Feel free to email me.I would also like to add that aside from the reality of whether or not these conversations are actually occurring, as your partner, he should be just as concerned about something that is disturbing you to this level.  Partners need each others' trust and support, no matter who is right or wrong.

I understand that you're carrying a heavy burden from your past experiences, which is impacting your current relationships. It takes great courage to acknowledge and confront past traumas. I applaud you for recognizing this as a crucial step towards healing and moving forward.  First, it seems essential for you to prioritize self-care and self-compassion. These experiences must have caused significant emotional pain, and it's ok to give yourself permission to grieve and process these emotions at your own pace.  Second, working with a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist, can play an essential role. This individual can help you develop coping strategies and healthy ways to process emotional pain as well as work through the traumatic memories.  They can assist in creating a safe space to explore feelings and emotions you may have avoided in the past. Furthermore, a mental health professional can offer various therapeutic approaches, including cognitive-behavioral techniques, mindfulness practices, and relaxation techniques to help you build resilience and improve emotional regulation.  Lastly, I encourage you to be patient with yourself throughout this healing process, as making progress towards recovery can be a gradual and non-linear experience. You've already taken the first step in acknowledging the impact of your past on your current life; continuing this commitment to your emotional wellbeing can bring about lasting change and the freedom to enjoy a happier and healthier future.  Your loving and caring partner may be your primary source of emotional support during this process. Their presence may enhance your healing journey and help strengthen the bond between you two. Communicating openly about your past traumas and how your past influences your emotional responses may bring you even closer together. This open and honest dialogue can also help in processing your feelings in a safe and compassionate environment.  In summary, acknowledging your past traumas is the first essential step towards healing. You're taking a great step in recognizing the impact of your experiences on your current emotional well-being. Working with a mental health professional, practicing self-compassion, and focusing on open communication with your partner can all help create a strong foundation for your recovery and long-term emotional growth.

Hi Louisiana,You say that the problems are with your "past", but my hunch is the problems are about his insecurity and his personal barriers to trust (unless you've recently revealed details of a sordid past?). You don't mention ever having hurt the trust in the relationship.Trust is the first stage in a relationship. Moving forward before they develop trust is a common mistake couples make, and now you two have involved children in a relationship that's missing a crucial element. But you didn't see this coming, did you? That's because only as we become emotionally intimate do our deeper fears and insecurities come to the surface. I give you credit for wanting it to work, and I believe you would benefit from the support of a therapist in working through the kinks related to trust. Good luck!

Have you ever tried talking with her about this when she's not angry? While I hear you saying that it feels like she doesn't love you, there could be a lot of other pieces to this. Have you ever told her about how much she means to you (when she's not angry)?

I understand that you're feeling low and disconnected from activities and people in your life, but these symptoms are not normal for everyone. Feeling tired all the time, lack of energy, loss of interest in activities, and irritability can be indicators of depression. It's important to talk about these feelings with a healthcare professional to determine if you're experiencing a depressive episode. They can help you identify the cause and provide appropriate treatment, such as therapy or medication. Remember, it's not a sign of weakness to ask for help. Depression is a common and treatable condition.

I understand. It can be challenging to maintain boundaries in relationships, especially when we feel deeply connected to others. Setting and respecting healthy boundaries is an important skill for maintaining emotional and mental wellbeing. This might involve practicing effective communication, learning how to say "no," and recognizing when it's necessary to take a break from certain interactions. Would you like to discuss specific strategies or techniques to help you with this? Or perhaps we could explore any underlying emotional or relational issues that might be making it difficult for you to set boundaries?

One way to know yourself a little better and why the dynamics you describe take place, is to understand the particular dynamics of your life context.Look at your major areas of where you spend your time, whether you are happy with the people with whom you socialize, how you feel toward family members and how they seem to feel toward you.If you examine your relationships and life this way then you may start to notice areas where you have some control or at least a say in how your life is going.If you are socializing among people whom you don't like, have a job you don't like and your family mistreats you and you mistreats them, for example, then anxiety and depression are an understandable natural result.If you make improvements in your life and relationships, even tiny improvements and even the effort and intention to improve, you may find your anxiety and depression dissipating.People usually feel their worst when they feel lack of control in their life.Look for ways you can regain and/or strengthen yours.

I understand that feeling of being overly dependent on someone can be distressing and limiting, leading to a loss of personal identity. It's important to remember that building independence is a process and it takes time. Here are a few steps you can take to reduce dependency in your relationship:  1. Identify your interests: Engage in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment outside of your relationship. Re-discover hobbies or explore new ones that you have always wanted to try. This can help you build a strong sense of self-worth and identity beyond your romantic relationship.  2. Build friendships: Cultivate relationships with friends and family members. Connecting with others can provide a support system and broaden your social circle. Building strong relationships with people outside of your romantic relationship can strengthen your sense of self and independence.  3. Practice self-care: Take time for yourself to focus on your physical, emotional and mental well-being. This can include activities like exercising, practicing mindfulness, meditating, reading, or pursuing creative pursuits.  4. Set personal goals: Setting personal goals can help build a sense of purpose and direction, as well as contribute to a feeling of personal accomplishment. These goals can be related to your career, hobbies, or any area of your life that you would like to improve or develop.  5. Communicate openly with your boyfriend: It's important to discuss your feelings of dependency with your boyfriend in a mindful and compassionate way. Encouraging him to support your journey towards independence while maintaining open and clear communication about your needs and boundaries can help strengthen your relationship and reinforce a healthy balance of autonomy and interdependence.

Anxiety can cause such a feeling of discomfort in our bodies that it can seem unbearable. The concern that I can hear in what you have written is that the thought of having some anxiety has now left you uncomfortable with any anxiety at all - and that can become a problem, indeed. As opposed to thinking about your anxiety as something much bigger than you, it could be helpful to start breaking it down. What are the things specifically that cause you anxiety about this new job? Is it being away from your family? If so, why? Once you start breaking down what causes you to feel anxiety into smaller "mouthfuls", then we are far better able to understand what has led to discomfort and start to problem solve the issue.

It sounds like you are feeling pretty overwhelmed with worry about being continuously monitored, with no privacy even in your own mind, and as if people are constantly saying things about you in whispers on in the media. It's hard to say from a post online what is at the root of this experience, but you may be able to get insight into that, as well as develop ways of coping with the distress of feeling this way, with the help of a good therapist.
